newsitem.title: USA: Fed Chairman Greenspan again rattles stock market.
newsitem.headline: Fed Chairman Greenspan again rattles stock market.

text.p: Stock prices fell Thursday after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan hinted that he was inching toward raising interest rates, possibly as early as next week.
Shortly before 11 a.m. EST, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 50.23 points at 6,827.45. In the broader market, declining issues beat advances 3-1.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond was off 7/32, and its yield jumped to 7.01 percent from Wednesday's close of 6.99 percent.
In prepared testimony to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Greenspan said that the economy retains "a great deal of vigor" and the jobs market is strong.
Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Co., said Greenspan has managed a 50 basis point rise in the long bond yield since his comments about "irrational exhuberance" in December.
"He is using his jawboning capacity to get markets to move. Whether he has to put an exclamation mark on it by raising rates is debatable," Barthel said.
The Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday to consider raising short-term interest rates for the first time in nearly two years.
Much of Greenspan's testimony seemed aimed at preparing lawmakers -- who have often been critical of Fed policy in the past -- for the possibility of a rate increase as soon as next week.
At next week's meeting, the FOMC will have to judge whether the strong pace of the economic expansion will continue and what impact that might eventually have on inflation, Greenspan said.
In addition to Greenspan's comments, the Dow was also suffering from a sell-off in stock of Philip Morris, which lost 4-5/8 to 117-3/8.
Philip Morris sank on news that state attorneys general are close to a settlement with Liggett, the tobacco unit of Brooke Group Ltd. Brooke Group shares were up 1/2 at 4-3/4.

"Philip Morris has weathered these kinds of events before, so one can argue it will survive again," Barthel said. "The big story for the company is international growth and not problems at home and how they will affect domestic growth."
The Nasdaq Composite index was off 0.55 point at 1,248.74 and the American Stock Exchange index slipped 0.99 to 590.80.
